fields.Title of Contribution: <span style="font-size:12pt;background-color:transparent;">Diverse Intimate Partner Violence Survivors’ Experiences of Seeking Help from the Police: A Qualitative Research Synthesis</span>
fields.Description/Abstract: Intimate partner violence (IPV) is an ongoing public health and criminal legal issue that<br>transcends social boundaries. However, there is a lack of equitable representation of diverse<br>populations who experience IPV in the literature. To garner a holistic knowledge of diverse IPV<br>survivor populations’ experiences with seeking help from the police, the current study utilized a<br>qualitative research synthesis methodology to explore police interactions among six non-<br>normative IPV survivor populations: women with substance use issues, immigrant women,<br>women in rural localities, heterosexual men, racial/ethnic minority women, and lesbian women.<br>Seven electronic databases were searched to identify peer-reviewed articles on IPV survivors;<br>narrative descriptions (qualitative or mixed methods) of their encounters with law enforcement.<br>The final analysis included 26 studies that were then coded with an iterative coding strategy. The<br>analysis uncovered the following themes: (1) revictimization by the police, (2) police negligence,<br>(3) discrimination, (4) cultural differences, and (5) positive experiences. These themes<br>demonstrated that while some experiences with law enforcement were shared between non-<br>normative survivor groups, some experiences were explicitly tied to the identities of the<br>survivors. Recognizing the potential law enforcement has to support survivors, the findings of<br>the current study reiterate the need for ongoing efforts to improve law enforcement knowledge<br>and overall response to IPV, especially for diverse populations of IPV survivors.
